Lad is the best Node.js framework. Made by a former Express TC and Koa team member.
A lad that fell in love with a lass • Built by @niftylettuce and contributors

Project Spotlight: Forward Email @ https://forwardemail.net (made with Lad)

Live Framework Demo: https://lad.sh

❤️ Love this project? Support @niftylettuce's FOSS on Patreon or PayPal 🦄

# Features

Lad boasts dozens of features and is extremely configurable.

# Microservices

These microservices are preconfigured for security, performance, and graceful reloading.

  • Webapp server → web.js
  • API server → api.js
  • Job scheduler → bree.js
  • Proxy server → proxy.js

# Front-end

  • Browser linting using eslint-plugin-compatopen in new window and browserslistopen in new window (see .browserslistrc for the default config)
  • Pugopen in new window template engine (you can easily use Moonopen in new window, Vueopen in new window, Reactopen in new window, or Angularopen in new window, though typically you aren't going to need itopen in new window)
  • Gulpopen in new window (latest version 4.x)
  • Sassopen in new window
  • PostCSSopen in new window (with font-magicianopen in new window, import-urlopen in new window, font-grabberopen in new window, base64open in new window, and cssnextopen in new window pre-configured)
  • Bootstrapopen in new window
  • Font Awesomeopen in new window
  • SpinKitopen in new window
  • SweetAlert2open in new window
  • Denseopen in new window
  • Waypointsopen in new window
  • LiveReloadopen in new window
  • …

# Back-end

  • Redis, sessions, and flash toast and modal SweetAlert2open in new window messages (uses ioredisopen in new window which has support for Clusteropen in new window, Sentinelopen in new window, and more)
  • Koa-based webapp and API servers (uses HTTP/2 for production!)
  • Pagination built-in (using ctx-paginateopen in new window)
  • RESTful API with BasicAuth and versioning
  • Automated job scheduler with cron and human-readable syntax (backed by Mongooseopen in new window and Breeopen in new window)
  • Passport-based authentication and group-based (Unix-like) permissioning
  • Stripe-inspired error handling
  • Mongoose and MongoDB with common database plugins
  • Email template engine with Nodemaileropen in new window and local rendering
  • Proxy eliminates need for Nginx reverse-proxy or Apache virtual hosts
  • Multilingual through built-in i18n translation support (see configuration)
  • Automatic phrase translation with Google Translate
  • Sitemap generator for simple SEO
  • …

# Translation

Finally a framework that solves i18n everywhere; complete with automatic translation.

  • Translation constants built-in so you don't repeat yourselfopen in new window
  • Webapp error messages and templates are translated
  • Emails are translated
  • API responses are translated
  • Database errors are translated
  • Authentication errors are translated
  • …

# Email Engine

Our beautiful email engine uses email-templatesopen in new window (which is also made by the creator of Lad)!

  • Test your emails locally with automatic browser-rendering on the fly
  • Automatically inlines CSS for cross-browser and cross-platform email client support
  • Use Bootstrapopen in new window in your email template designs
  • Reuse your existing CSS and webapp styling
  • Use any template engine (defaults to Pug)
  • Render custom fonts in emails with codeopen in new window
  • Add icons with Font Awesome with codeopen in new window
  • Automatically avoid email client cachingopen in new window
  • Include any image you want and it will be properly rendered
  • Rids the need for awkward embedded image CID attachments
  • …

# Error Handling

We've spent a lot of time designing a beautiful error handler.

  • Supports text/html, application/json, and text response types
  • User-friendly responsesopen in new window
  • HTML error listsopen in new window
  • …

See koa-better-error-handleropen in new window for a complete reference.

# Performance

  • Compression and zero-bloat approach
  • Stream-based file uploading
  • Graceful reloading, shutdown, and reconnection handling
  • Manifest asset revisioning
  • Amazon S3 and CloudFront ready
  • …

# Security

  • Database security plugins and helpers
  • Automated tests and code coverage
  • CORS, SameSite set to "lax" (an alternative to CSRFopen in new window), CSRF (since not all browsersopen in new window support SameSite yet) XSS, and rate limited protection
  • Dotenv support for environment-based configurations
  • App, user, and request-based logging
  • SSL-ready (see instructions below)
  • …

# Get Started

We strictly support Mac and Ubuntu-based operating systems (we do not support Windows).

# Requirements

Please ensure your operating system has the following software installed:

  • Gitopen in new window - see GitHub's tutorialopen in new window for installation

  • Node.jsopen in new window (v10+) - use nvmopen in new window to install it on any OS

    • After installing nvm you will need to run nvm install node
    • We also recommend you install yarnopen in new window, which is an alternative to npmopen in new window

  • MongoDBopen in new window (v3.x+):

    • Mac (via brewopen in new window): brew tap mongodb/brew && brew install mongodb-community && brew services start mongodb-community.

    • Ubuntu:

      sudo apt-key adv --keyserver hkp://keyserver.ubuntu.com:80 --recv 0C49F3730359A14518585931BC711F9BA15703C6
echo "deb http://repo.mongodb.org/apt/ubuntu "$(lsb_release -sc)"/mongodb-org/3.4 multiverse" | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/mongodb-org-3.4.list
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get -y install mongodb-org
      1
      2
      3
      4

  • Redisopen in new window (v4.x+):

    • Mac (via brewopen in new window): brew install redis && brew services start redis

    • Ubuntu:

      sudo add-apt-repository -y ppa:chris-lea/redis-server
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get -y install redis-server
      1
      2
      3

# Install

npmopen in new window:

npm install -g lad
1

yarnopen in new window:

yarn global add lad
1

# Usage

# Create a project

lad new-project
cd new-project
1
2

# Development

To begin, try typing npm start (or yarn start) on command line. This will display to you all the scripts you can run.

The start script (among many others) uses npsopen in new window and nps-utilsopen in new window under the hood. This helps to keep scripts very developer-friendly, and rids the need to write in JSON syntax.

This script accepts a <task> argument, whereas a task of all will spawn, watch, and re-compile all of the microservices mentioned above.

Just open http://localhost:3000open in new window for testing!

npmopen in new window:

npm start all
1

yarnopen in new window:

yarn start all
1
# Debugging

  • DEBUG - debug using debugopen in new window output (widely adopted package in the community for debugging across all Node packages):

    DEBUG=* ...
    1

  • NODE_DEBUG - debug nodeopen in new window internal modules:

    NODE_DEBUG=* ...
    1

  • MONGOOSE_DEBUG - debug Mongoose raw database operation output:

    MONGOOSE_DEBUG=true ...
    1

  • TRANSPORT_DEBUG - debug Nodemailer transport:

    TRANSPORT_DEBUG=true ...
    1

  • REDIS_MONITOR - debug Redis using MONITOR (uses @ladjs/redisopen in new window and passes true for the monitor argument):

    REDIS_MONITOR=true ...
    1

  • REDIS_FRIENDLY_ERROR_STACK - debug Redis with friendly error stack messages (see showFriendlyErrorStackopen in new window option of ioredisopen in new window)

    REDIS_FRIENDLY_ERROR_STACK=true ...
    1

# Production

We strongly recommend using SemaphoreCIopen in new window, PM2open in new window, and Digital Oceanopen in new window for production deployment.

  1. We've provided you with a preconfigured ecosystem.json deployment fileopen in new window. You will need to modify this file with your server's IP, hostname, and other metadata if needed.

  2. Make sure that your project's assets are built with NODE_ENV=production flag, e.g. NODE_ENV=production npm run build (or with yarn as yarn build);this creates a build/rev-manifest.json file per koa-manifest-revopen in new window.

  3. You can test this locally by installing PM2open in new window globally with npmopen in new window or yarnopen in new window, and then running the following command:

    NODE_ENV=production pm2 start
    1

  4. See the Continuous Integration and Code Coverage and Tutorials sections below for instructions on how to setup continuous integration, code coverage, and deployment.

  5. If you specify an environment variable value for AWS_CF_DOMAIN and NODE_ENV=production is set then your assets will need to be published to Amazon S3/Cloudfront. To do so run npm start publish-assets (or with yarn as yarn start publish-assets). This command automatically sets NODE_ENV=production for you as well via cross-env.

# Provisioning

See the ansible folder for our Ansibleopen in new window configuration and playbooks, which we use to provision servers with.

We recommend you to install yamllintopen in new window and configure it in your editor while working with Ansibleopen in new window playbooks.

Also note that ansible-lintopen in new window is a helpful linting tool you can use if you plan on making changes to playbooks. Note that our current playbooks have several existing lint errors.

First you must provision Ubuntu 18.04 LTS 64-bit server(s) using Digital Oceanopen in new window, Linodeopen in new window, Vultropen in new window, or your host of choice. These newly provisioned server(s) should have your SSH key automatically added.

Follow the Deployment guide below for automatic provisioning and deployment instructions.

# Deployment

  1. Set up host configuration by copying the hosts.yml file template:

    cp ansible/playbooks/templates/hosts.yml hosts.yml
    1

  2. Edit this configuration and update the file with your newly created server aliases and IP addresses. You can add more than one host to each group if you are setting up load balancing. Refer to the Naming Convention documentation for our recommended approach to server alias naming. Note that this file is automatically ignored by git. If you have a private repository and would like to commit this, then remove hosts.yml from the root .gitignore file.

    vim hosts.yml
    1

  3. Set up environment configuration by copying the env file template:

    cp ansible/playbooks/templates/env .env.production
    1

  4. Edit this configuration and reference the official Ladopen in new window documentation for a list of all available environment variables (or see .env.defaults). You will need to open this file in your preferred editor and set the values for any fields containing TODO, whereby you replace TODO with the appropriate value. Preserve double quotes where they are already defined.

    vim .env.production
    1

  5. Generate pm2open in new window ecosystem filesopen in new window using our automatic template generator. We created an ansible-playbook.js which loads the .env.production environment variables rendered with @ladjs/envopen in new window into process.env, which then gets used in the playbooks. This is a superior, simple, and the only known dotenv approach we know of in Ansible. Newly created ecosystem-api.json, ecosystem-bree.json, ecosystem-web.json files will now be created for you in the root of the repository. If you ever more add or change IP addresses, you can simply re-run this command.

    node ansible-playbook ansible/playbooks/ecosystem.yml -l 'localhost'
    1

  6. Set up the web and API server(s) (see patterns and ansible-playbook flags docsopen in new window if you need help). If you completely (or partially) run this playbook (or any others below), then the second time you try to run it may not succeed. This is because we prevent root user access through security hardening. To workaround this, run the same command but without -e 'ansible_user=root' appended as it will default to the devops user created.

    node ansible-playbook ansible/playbooks/http.yml -e 'ansible_user=root' -l 'http'
    1

  7. Set up the Bree server(s):

    node ansible-playbook ansible/playbooks/bree.yml -e 'ansible_user=root' -l 'bree'
    1

  8. Set up the Redis server:

    node ansible-playbook ansible/playbooks/redis.yml -e 'ansible_user=root' -l 'redis'
    1

  9. Set up the Mongo server:

    node ansible-playbook ansible/playbooks/mongo.yml -e 'ansible_user=root' -l 'mongo'
    1

  10. Set up GitHub deployment keys for all the servers. Note that the deployment-keys directory is ignored from git, so if you have a private repository and wish to commit it, then remove deployment-keys from the .gitignore file.

    node ansible-playbook ansible/playbooks/deployment-keys.yml -l 'http:bree'
    1

  11. Go to your repository "Settings" page on GitHub, click on "Deploy keys", and then add a deployment key for each servers' deployment key copied to the deployment-keys directory. If you're on macOS, you can use the pbcopy command to copy each file's contents to your clipboard. Use tab completion for speed, and replace the server names and paths with yours:

    cat deployment-keys/api-1-li-dal.forwardemail.net.pub | pbcopy

#
# NOTE: repeat the above command for all servers
# and after running the command, it will copy
# the key to your clipboard for you to paste as
# a new deploy key (make sure to use read-only access)
#
    1
    2
    3
    4
    5
    6
    7
    8

  12. Set up PM2 deployment directories on all the servers:

    pm2 deploy ecosystem-web.json production setup
    1
    pm2 deploy ecosystem-api.json production setup
    1
    pm2 deploy ecosystem-bree.json production setup
    1

  13. Create a SSL certificate at Namecheapopen in new window (we recommend a 5 year wildcard certificate), set up the certificate, and download and extract the ZIP file with the certificate (emailed to you) to your computer. We do not recommend using tools like LetsEncryptopen in new window and certbot due to complexity when you have (or scale to) a cluster of servers set up behind load balancers. In other words, we've tried approaches like lsyncd in combination with crontab for certbot renewals and automatic checking. Furthermore, using this exposes the server(s) to downtime as ports 80 and 443 may need to be shut down so that certbot can use them for certificate generation. This is not a reliable approach, and simply renewing certificates once a year is vastly simpler and also makes using load balancers trivial. Instead you can use a provider like Namecheapopen in new window to get a cheap SSL certificate, then run a few commands as we've documented below. This command will prompt you for an absolute file path to the certificates you downloaded. Renewed your certificate after 1 year? Simply follow this step again. Do not set a password on the certificate files. When using the openssl command (see Namecheap instructions), you need to use *.example.com with an asterisk followed by a period if you are registering a wildcard certificate.

    ansible-playbook ansible/playbooks/certificates.yml
    1

    Important: If you renew or change certificates in the future, then after running the previous command, you will subsequently need to reload the processes as such:

    #
# NOTE: See the "Important" note above BEFORE running this command.
#       This command ONLY APPLIES for certificate renewals/changes.
#
pm2 deploy ecosystem-web.json production exec "pm2 reload web"
pm2 deploy ecosystem-api.json production exec "pm2 reload api"
    1
    2
    3
    4
    5
    6

  14. (Optional) Create a Google application credentials profile file and store it locally. You only need this if you want to support automatic translation. The following command will prompt you for the absolute file path (e.g. /path/to/client-profile.json). See the mandarinopen in new window docs for more information.

    ansible-playbook ansible/playbooks/gapp-creds.yml -l 'http:bree'
    1

  15. Copy the .env.production file and create an AWS config file on the servers:

    node ansible-playbook ansible/playbooks/env.yml -l 'http:bree'
    1

  16. Run an initial deploy to all the servers:

    pm2 deploy ecosystem-web.json production
    1
    pm2 deploy ecosystem-api.json production
    1
    pm2 deploy ecosystem-bree.json production
    1

  17. Save the process list on the servers so when if the server were to reboot, it will automatically boot back up the processes:

    pm2 deploy ecosystem-web.json production exec "pm2 save"
    1
    pm2 deploy ecosystem-api.json production exec "pm2 save"
    1
    pm2 deploy ecosystem-bree.json production exec "pm2 save"
    1

  18. Test by visiting your web and API server in your browser (click "proceed to unsafe" site and bypass certificate warning).

  19. Configure your DNS records for the web and API server hostnames and respective IP addresses.

  20. Test by visiting your web and API server in your browser (in an incognito window). There should not be any certificate warnings (similar to the one that occurred in step 15).

  21. (Optional) Remove the local .env.production file for security purposes. If you do this, then make sure you have a backup, or securely back up off the server in the future before destroying the server.

    rm .env.production
    1

  22. (Optional) Remove the local certificate files you downloaded locally and specified in step 11. If you do this, then make sure you have a backup, or securely back up off the server in the future before destroying the server.

  23. Finished. If you need to deploy again, then push your changes to GitHub master branch and then follow step 14 again. We recommend you to read the Ansible getting started guideopen in new window, as it provides you with insight into commands like ansible all -a "echo hello" which can be run across all or specific servers.

# Tests

We use avaopen in new window and nycopen in new window for testing and code coverage.

npmopen in new window:

npm test
1

yarnopen in new window:

yarn test
1

# Configuration

# Environment Variables

We have made configuration of your Lad project easy through a dotenvopen in new window configuration package called @ladjs/envopen in new window, per Twelve-Factoropen in new window.

We use the following three packages to manage configuration:

  • dotenv-extendedopen in new window - allows us to craft a .env definition (otherwise known as a "schema") in a file named .env.schema
  • mustacheopen in new window - allows us to use the Mustache templating languageopen in new window in our .env and .env.defaults configuration files
  • dotenv-parse-variablesopen in new window - automatically parses variable types from process.env (e.g. FOO=4 will set process.env.FOO = 4 with a Number variable type instead of a String)

Configuration is managed by the following, in order of priority:

  1. Contents of the file at config/index.js (reads in process.env environment variables)
  2. Contents of the files in directories under config/environments/ (sets defaults per environment, e.g. you can pass NODE_ENV=staging and it will load the file at config/environments/staging.js)
  3. Environment variables used to override defaults or set required ones (e.g. NODE_ENV=production)
  4. Environment configuration in .env
  5. Environment configuration in .env.defaults

Precedence is taken by the environment configuration files, environment variables, then the .env file.

Basically dotenvopen in new window won't set an environment variable if it already detects it was passed as an environment variable.

Take a look at the config folder contents and also at the defaults at .env.defaults.

  • NODE_ENV - (options: development, production default: development) - the node environment the app is running in
  • PROXY_PORT - (default: 8080) - proxy port used to proxy requests (see ladjs/proxyopen in new window)
  • HTTP_PROTOCOL - (defaults: http recommend: https) - protocol used for http requests
  • HTTP_PORT - (defaults: 80 recommend: 443) - http port used for http requests
  • WEB_PROTOCOL - (default: http) - ladjs/webopen in new window application protocol
  • WEB_HOST - (default: localhost) - ladjs/webopen in new window application host
  • WEB_PORT - (default: 3000) - ladjs/webopen in new window application port
  • WEB_URL - (default: ://:) - web application absolute URI
  • WEB_SSL_KEY_PATH - ladjs/webopen in new window file path to your SSL key file
  • WEB_SSL_CERT_PATH - ladjs/webopen in new window file path to your SSL certificate file
  • WEB_SSL_CA_PATH - ladjs/webopen in new window file path to your SSL certificate authority file
  • API_HOST - (default: localhost) - ladjs/apiopen in new window host
  • API_PORT - (default: 4000) - ladjs/apiopen in new window port
  • API_PROTOCOL - (default: http recommend: https) - ladjs/apiopen in new window protocol
  • API_URL - (default: ://:) - ladjs/apiopen in new window absolute URI
  • API_SSL_KEY_PATH - ladjs/apiopen in new window file path to your SSL key file
  • API_SSL_CERT_PATH - ladjs/apiopen in new window file path to your SSL certificate file
  • API_SSL_CA_PATH - ladjs/apiopen in new window file path to your SSL certificate authority file
  • API_RATELIMIT_WHITELIST - ladjs/apiopen in new window ratelimiter whitelisted ips (see: koa-simple-ratelimitopen in new window)
  • APP_NAME - (default: Lad) - application name (see usageopen in new window)
  • APP_COLOR - application color theme (see usageopen in new window)
  • TWITTER - (default: @niftylettuce) twitter handle
  • SEND_EMAIL - (default: false) - whether to send email or preview (see outbound email configurationopen in new window)
  • TRANSPORT_DEBUG - (default: false) - email transport debug logging (see debuggingopen in new window)
  • EMAIL_DEFAULT_FROM - (default: support@127.0.01) - default email from address
  • SHOW_STACK - (default: true) - whether or not to output a stack trace when logging (see cabinjs optionsopen in new window)
  • SHOW_META - (default: true) - whether or not to output metadata to logger methods (see cabinjs optionsopen in new window)
  • SUPPORT_REQUEST_MAX_LENGTH - (default: 500) - support request max message size in characters
  • ERROR_HANDLER_BASE_URL - (default: ) error handling base url (see koa-better-error-handleropen in new window)
  • I18N_SYNC_FILES - (default: true) - sync locale information across all files (see ladjs/i18n optionsopen in new window)
  • I18N_AUTO_RELOAD - (default: false) - watch for changes in json files to reload locale on updates (see ladjs/i18n optionsopen in new window)
  • I18N_UPDATE_FILES - (default: true) - write new locale information to disk (see ladjs/i18n optionsopen in new window)
  • AUTH_LOCAL_ENABLED - (default: true) - enable passport local strategy (see ladjs/passportopen in new window)
  • AUTH_FACEBOOK_ENABLED - (default: false) - enable authenticating with Facebook using the OAuth 2.0 (see ladjs/passportopen in new window)
  • AUTH_TWITTER_ENABLED - (default: false) - enable authenticating with Twitter using the OAuth 1.0 (see ladjs/passportopen in new window)
  • AUTH_GOOGLE_ENABLED - (default: false) - enable authenticating with Google using OAuth 2.0 (see google authopen in new window)
  • AUTH_GITHUB_ENABLED - (default: false) - enable authenticating with Github using OAuth 2.0 (see ladjs/passportopen in new window)
  • AUTH_LINKEDIN_ENABLED - (default: false) - enable authenticating with LinkedIn using OAuth 1.0 (see ladjs/passportopen in new window)
  • AUTH_INSTAGRAM_ENABLED - (default: false) - enable authenticating with Instagram using OAuth 2.0 (see ladjs/passportopen in new window)
  • AUTH_OTP_ENABLED - (default: false) - enable authenticating with OTP, a form of two-factor authentication (see ladjs/passportopen in new window)
  • AUTH_STRIPE_ENABLED - (default: false) - enable authenticating with Stripe using OAuth 2.0 (see ladjs/passportopen in new window)
  • GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID - google oauth2 client id (see google authopen in new window)
  • GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET - google oauth2 secret (see google authopen in new window)
  • GOOGLE_CALLBACK_URL - google oauth2 callback url (see google authopen in new window)
  • GOOGLE_APPLICATION_CREDENTIALS - path to google cloud platform credentials (see gcp credentialsopen in new window)
  • GITHUB_CLIENT_ID - github oauth client id (see ladjs/passportopen in new window)
  • GITHUB_CLIENT_SECRET - github oauth secret (see ladjs/passportopen in new window)
  • GITHUB_CALLBACK_URL - github oauth callback URL (see ladjs/passportopen in new window)
  • POSTMARK_API_TOKEN - postmark api token (see outbound email configurationopen in new window)
  • CODECOV_TOKEN - codecov api token (see continuous integration and code coverageopen in new window)
  • MONGO_USER - mongodb username
  • MONGO_PASS - mongodb password
  • MONGO_HOST - (default: localhost) - mongodb hostname
  • MONGO_PORT - (default: 27017) - mongodb port
  • MONGO_NAME - (default: _) - mongodb name
  • MONGO_URI - (default: mongodb://:/) - mongodb connection URI
  • WEB_MONGO_USER - ladjs/webopen in new window mongodb username
  • WEB_MONGO_PASS - ladjs/webopen in new window mongodb password
  • WEB_MONGO_HOST - ladjs/webopen in new window mongodb hostname
  • WEB_MONGO_NAME - ladjs/webopen in new window mongodb name
  • WEB_MONGO_PORT - ladjs/webopen in new window mongodb port
  • WEB_MONGO_URI - ladjs/webopen in new window mongodb connection URI
  • API_MONGO_USER - ladjs/apiopen in new window mongodb username
  • API_MONGO_PASS - ladjs/apiopen in new window mongodb password
  • API_MONGO_HOST - ladjs/apiopen in new window mongodb hostname
  • API_MONGO_NAME - ladjs/apiopen in new window mongodb name
  • API_MONGO_PORT - ladjs/apiopen in new window mongodb port
  • API_MONGO_URI - ladjs/apiopen in new window mongodb connection URI
  • BREE_MONGO_USER - breejs/breeopen in new window mongodb username
  • BREE_MONGO_PASS - breejs/breeopen in new window mongodb password
  • BREE_MONGO_HOST - breejs/breeopen in new window mongodb hostname
  • BREE_MONGO_NAME - breejs/breeopen in new window mongodb name
  • BREE_MONGO_PORT - breejs/breeopen in new window mongodb port
  • BREE_MONGO_URI - breejs/breeopen in new window mongodb connection URI
  • REDIS_PORT - (default: 6379) - redis port
  • REDIS_HOST - (default: localhost) - redis hostname
  • REDIS_PASSWORD - redis password
  • WEB_REDIS_PORT - ladjs/webopen in new window redis port
  • WEB_REDIS_HOST - ladjs/webopen in new window redis hostname
  • WEB_REDIS_PASSWORD - ladjs/webopen in new window redis password
  • API_REDIS_PORT - ladjs/apiopen in new window redis port
  • API_REDIS_HOST - ladjs/apiopen in new window redis hostname
  • API_REDIS_PASSWORD - ladjs/apiopen in new window redis password
  • BREE_REDIS_PORT - breejs/breeopen in new window redis port
  • BREE_REDIS_HOST - breejs/breeopen in new window redis hostname
  • BREE_REDIS_PASSWORD - breejs/breeopen in new window redis password
  • MANDARIN_REDIS_PORT - mandarinopen in new window redis port
  • MANDARIN_REDIS_HOST - mandarinopen in new window redis hostname
  • MANDARIN_REDIS_PASSWORD - mandarinopen in new window redis password
  • CERTBOT_WELL_KNOWN_NAME - letsencrypt wellknown name (see certbot optionsopen in new window)
  • CERTBOT_WELL_KNOWN_CONTENTS - letsencrypt wellknown contents (see certbot optionsopen in new window)
  • VERIFICATION_PIN_TIMEOUT_MS - (default: 5m) - email verification pin expiry
  • VERIFICATION_PIN_EMAIL_INTERVAL_MS - (default: 1m) - email verification pin email interval
  • API_SECRETS - (default: secret) - list of restricted api secrets
  • CACHE_RESPONSES - (default: false) - cache specified responses (see ladjs/koa-cache-responsesopen in new window)
  • SLACK_API_TOKEN - slack api token (see slack web apiopen in new window)

# SSL Configuration

To configure SSL for the web or API server simply set them in your .env file or pass them as environment variables.

Web server:

  • WEB_PROTOCOL - you must set this to https
  • WEB_SSL_KEY_PATH - file path to your SSL key file (e.g. /home/deploy/.ssl/web-key.pem)
  • WEB_SSL_CERT_PATH - file path to your SSL certificate file (e.g. /home/deploy/.ssl/web-cert.pem)
  • WEB_SSL_CA_PATH (optional) - file path to your SSL certificate authority file (e.g. /home/deploy/.ssl/web-ca-cert.pem)

API server:

  • API_PROTOCOL - you must set this to https
  • API_SSL_KEY_PATH - file path to your SSL key file (e.g. /home/deploy/.ssl/api-key.pem)
  • API_SSL_CERT_PATH - file path to your SSL certificate file (e.g. /home/deploy/.ssl/api-cert.pem)
  • API_SSL_CA_PATH (optional) - file path to your SSL certificate authority file (e.g. /home/deploy/.ssl/api-ca-cert.pem)

# Outbound Email Configuration

By default in the development environment we simply render the email in your browser.

However in other environments such as production, you definitely want emails to be sent.

We built-in support for Postmark by default (though you can swap in your own transport provider in the jobs/email.js file):

  1. Go to https://postmarkapp.comopen in new window – Start Free Trial

  2. Create a free trial account, then click Get Started, and proceed to create a "Server" and "Sender Signature"

  3. Copy/paste the "Server API token" under "Credentials" in your .env file (example below)

    -POSTMARK_API_TOKEN=
+POSTMARK_API_TOKEN=ac6657eb-2732-4cfd-915b-912b1b10beb1
    1
    2

  4. Modify the SEND_EMAIL variable in .env from false to true

# Favicon and Touch Icon Configuration

You can customize the favicon and touch icons – just generate a new set at https://realfavicongenerator.netopen in new window and overwrite the existing in the assets folder.

Just make sure that any relative paths match up in the assets/browserconfig.xml and assets/manifest.json files.

# Authentication Methods

We use Lad's auth package under the hood; so if you want to configure authentication providers you'll want to read more or contribute to @ladjs/authopen in new window.

# Google Auth

In order to add Google sign-in to your app (so users can log in with their Google account):

  1. Go to https://console.developers.google.comopen in new window – Create a project (and fill out your project information – if you need a 120x120px default image, you can use this oneopen in new window with a CDN path of https://cdn.rawgit.com/ladjs/lad/82d38d64/media/lad-120x120.pngopen in new window

  2. Under your newly created project, go to Credentials – Create credentials – OAuth client ID – Web application

  3. Set "Authorized JavaScript origins" to http://yourdomain.com (replace with your domain) and also http://localhost:3000 (for local development)

  4. Set "Authorized redirect URIs" to http://yourdomain.com/auth/google/ok (again, replace with your domain) and also http://localhost:3000/auth/google/ok (again, for local development)

  5. Copy and paste the newly created key pair for respective properties in your .env file (example below)

    -GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID=
+GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID=424623312719-73vn8vb4tmh8nht96q7vdbn3mc9pd63a.apps.googleusercontent.com
-GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET=
+GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET=Oys6WrHleTOksqXTbEY_yi07
    1
    2
    3
    4

  6. In .env, make sure that AUTH_GOOGLE_ENABLED=true to enable this authentication method.

# Translation Configuration

  1. Go to https://console.developers.google.comopen in new window
  2. Enable the Google Translate API
  3. Copy your API key and set it as the environment variable GOOGLE_TRANSLATE_KEY=******

# Continuous Integration and Code Coverage

We strongly recommend that you use SemaphoreCIopen in new window for continuous integration and Codecovopen in new window for code coverage.

Here are the simple steps required to setup SemaphoreCIopen in new window with Codecovopen in new window:

  1. Go to SemaphoreCIopen in new window and sign up for a free account

  2. Once your repository is pushed to GitHub, add it as a project on SemaphoreCI

  3. Configure your project on SemaphoreCI with the following build settings:

    Replace npm with yarn if you're using yarnopen in new window as your package manager

    • Language: JavaScript
    • Node.js version: 10+ (latest LTS)

      Note you can also add to Setup the script nvm install latest to install latest version if SemaphoreCI does not provide it from the drop-down

    • Setup: npm install
    • Job 1: npm run test-coverage
    • After job: npm run coverage

  4. Go to Codecovopen in new window and sign up for a free account

  5. Add your project on Codecov and copy to your clipboard the token

  6. Go to SemaphoreCI's Project Settings for your project and add CODECOV_TOKEN as an environment variable (with the contents from your clipboard)

  7. Run a test build ("Rebuild last revision") on SemaphoreCI and check to make sure your code coverage report uploads properly on Codecov

  8. Ensure your README.md file has the build status and code coverage badges rendered properly (you will need to use a different badge link from each provider if your GitHub repository is private)

# Amazon S3 and CloudFront Asset Setup

In order for your assets to get properly served in a production environment, you'll need to configure AWS:

  1. Go to https://console.aws.amazon.com/iam/home#security_credentialopen in new window ‐ Access Keys – Create New Access Key

  2. Copy and paste the newly created key pair for respective properties in your .env file (example below)

    -AWS_IAM_KEY=
+AWS_IAM_KEY=AKIAJMH22P6W674YFC7Q
-AWS_IAM_SECRET=
+AWS_IAM_SECRET=9MpR1FOXwPEtPlrlU5WbHjnz2KDcKWSUcB+C5CpS
    1
    2
    3
    4

  3. Enable your API by clicking on Overview and then clicking the Enable button

  4. Go to https://console.aws.amazon.com/s3/homeopen in new window – Create Bucket

  5. Create a bucket and copy/paste its name for the property in .env (example below)

    -AWS_S3_BUCKET=
+AWS_S3_BUCKET=lad-development
    1
    2

  6. Go to https://console.aws.amazon.com/cloudfront/homeopen in new window – Create Distribution – Get Started

  7. Set "Origin Domain Name" equal to your S3 bucket name (their autocomplete drop-down will help you find it)

  8. Leave the remaining defaults as is (some fields might be blank, this is OK)

  9. Copy/paste the newly created Distribution ID and Domain Name for respective properties in your .env file (example below)

    -AWS_CF_DI=
+AWS_CF_DI=E2IBEULE9QOPVE
-AWS_CF_DOMAIN=
+AWS_CF_DOMAIN=d36aditw73gdrz.cloudfront.net
    1
    2
    3
    4

# Principles

Lad is designed according to these principles:

  1. Always be developer-friendly
  2. Adhere to MVCopen in new window, Unixopen in new window, KISSopen in new window, DRYopen in new window, YAGNIopen in new window, Twelve Factoropen in new window, Occam's razoropen in new window, and dogfoodingopen in new window
  3. Target the scrappy, bootstrapped, and ramen-profitableopen in new window hacker

# Related

  • lipoopen in new window - Free image manipulation API service built on top of Sharpopen in new window
  • cabinopen in new window - Logging and analytics solution for Node.jsopen in new window, Ladopen in new window, Koaopen in new window, and Expressopen in new window
  • lassopen in new window - Scaffold a modern boilerplate for Node.jsopen in new window

# Contributing

Interesting in contributing to this project or testing early releases?

  1. Follow all of the above Requirements

  2. You will need to fork and clone this repository locally

  3. After forking, follow these steps:

    cd lad
yarn install
cd template
yarn install
yarn start
    1
    2
    3
    4
    5

If you'd like to preview changes to the README.md file, you can use docute.

yarn global add docute-cli
cd lad
docute ./
1
2
3

Then visit http://localhost:8080open in new window in your browser.
